The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a matter of some controversy. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical characterization of the category of Hilbert space operators, which is the mathematical foundation of quantum theory as developed by von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in a wide range of animals. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a cnidarian species. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan was reduced to a minimal structure, and that the genome was reduced to one of the smallest reported in animals. This study provides insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has caused a global health crisis. The SARS-CoV-2 virus is able to evade the host immune response by blocking the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). In this study, we show that the viral accessory protein Orf6 is able to block nuclear import of ISGs by directly interacting with the Nup98-Rae1 complex. We also show that a simple mutation in Orf6 abolishes its ability to block nuclear import. Our findings provide a mechanistic understanding of how SARS-CoV-2 is able to evade the antiviral action of IFN. This knowledge may help to design new antiviral strategies to combat the ongoing pandemic. (Show more)

The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the Hv1. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food is expected to increase by 50% to meet this demand. This study shows that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase almost everywhere in the world, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase substantially in the top four maize-exporting countries. This study also shows that the instability of global maize production will increase, and the instability of global grain trade and international grain prices will increase as well. These results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level diet. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption inferred from DNA sequence relative read abundance ranged from >99% (plains zebra) to <1% (dik-dik). Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the need for more comprehensive and species-level diet information in future studies of herbivore ecology and coexistence. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses. We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the crisis on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act loans, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is far less than expected, mostly due to size-selective sinks. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. This study is of great importance to the scientific community and to the public.

The origin of the solar system is still a matter of debate. One of the most important questions is the age of the solar system. We determined the age of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. A majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. These grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. A minority of the grains have ages >1 Ga. Longer lifetimes are expected for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This result is important for the understanding of the solar system. It is also important for the understanding of the origin of presolar grains.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to reproduce is one of the most important traits in nature. In this study, we investigate the factors that increase reproductive output. We find that all forms of provisioning (allocare and domestication) increase reproductive output. We also find that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This study provides insight into the evolution of reproductive strategies in mammals. It also provides a framework for understanding the evolution of reproductive strategies in other species.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the striatum. The disease is fatal within a few years after disease onset. The cytopathological hallmark of MSA is the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. Here, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the progressive toxicity of α-syn aggregation in a mouse model of MSA. This suggests that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study opens the way for further preclinical and clinical studies. The results also suggest that α-syn aggregation is a common pathogenic mechanism in synucleinopathies. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform these functions. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling blood pressure and blood flow. To control each function, the endothelium receives information from multiple sources. Here, we show that the endothelium is connected in a network of cells that is highly efficient in the transmission of information. The endothelium is able to rapidly and efficiently integrate information from multiple sources to control vascular function. This is important for the health of the cardiovascular system.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. We describe the design and implementation of the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 indicators, including many auxiliary signals that are not available elsewhere. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as heart rate regulation, blood pressure control, and muscle contraction. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled in this ion-channel family. An allosteric coupling underlies C-type inactivation coupled to activation gating in this ion-channel family. We have identified the second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this residue is essential for the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter on activation. Finally, we have shown that the selectivity filter can be structurally collapsed by closing the channel’s activation gate.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical to the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is still being elucidated, and the potential for natural products to regulate the composition of the microbiome is an emerging area of research. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. We identify a large number of genes that encode biosynthetic enzymes for natural products, and we show that these fungi produce a variety of natural products. These results support the hypothesis that anaerobic fungi synthesize natural products and suggest that these fungi could be a source of novel bioactive compounds.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the underlying mechanisms remain largely unknown. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that is associated with a high risk of becoming subordinate, directly influences social dominance in rats. We identify the nucleus accumbens as a brain region that is crucial for the establishment of social hierarchy and show that high-anxious rats are prone to become subordinate due to reduced mitochondrial function in this brain region. We further demonstrate that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals can be reversed by enhancing brain energy metabolism in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of anxiety in social behavior and may lead to the development of new therapeutic approaches for anxiety disorders. The design of mechanical structures with desired responses is a fundamental problem in engineering. However, the design space is restricted by the limited knowledge of material properties and the structural patterns are often developed through trial and error. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to discover optimal composite structures that can precisely realize arbitrary and extreme responses under large deformations. The structures are digitally synthesized through a free-form inverse design approach, which is based on the principle of material response. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed strategy can be extended to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. The discovery of optimal composite structures with complex and programmable responses provides a new paradigm for the design of mechanical systems. The multimaterial fabrication and heteroassembly strategy can also be extended to design multifunctional and heterogeneous structures. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein in red blood cells. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroblasts is a function of the developmental stage of the cells. In this study, we investigated the role of a protein that is a downstream element of the let-7 miRNA pathway, insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1), in the control of hemoglobin expression in human erythroblasts. We found that IGF2BP1 is downregulated in fetal liver and upregulated in adult bone marrow. We show that IGF2BP1 can reprogram hemoglobin expression in human erythroblasts toward a more fetal-like pattern. This study suggests a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This may have implications for the understanding of hemoglobinopathies and for the development of therapeutic strategies for hemoglobinopathies. This article is protected by copyright. Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. Despite the advances in cancer treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to treatment. In this study, we found that the activation of PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. We also found that the activation of PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway protects cancer cells from oxidative stress and ferroptotic death through sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1-mediated lipogenesis. In addition, we found that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanisms of ferroptosis and suggest that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction may be a promising strategy for cancer treatment. Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is a major challenge for the medical community. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are effective, but they have side effects. We show that the three major classes of calcium channel blockers activate the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stromal-interacting molecule (STIM) Ca2+ sensor proteins and the plasma membrane ORAI Ca2+ channels. Our data indicate that these drugs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our findings unravel a mechanism of LCCBs action on Ca2+ signaling and demonstrate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. This study provides a new perspective on the mechanism of action of calcium channel blockers and may lead to the development of new drugs for treating hypertension and heart failure. This study may also lead to the development of new drugs for treating hypertension and heart failure.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the management of 10 million hectares of federal forest in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP’s effects on bird populations are complex and not as straightforward as expected. We found that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral bird populations, but the opposite was true for older-forest–associated species. This is partly explained by the fact that the NWFP did not halt clearcutting on federal land, which continues to be a threat to older forests. Our findings highlight the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The predicted best candidate is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Notably, the best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often very large, which makes them difficult to train and apply in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. Before 800 ka, lake levels were lower, indicating a climate drier than today, and water levels changed frequently. Following the MPT high-amplitude lake level variations dominate the record. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) suppresses melatonin and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

CTLA-4 is a negative regulator of T cell activation, but its specific role in the development of autoimmune diseases is still unclear. Here, we show that the loss of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to a spectrum of autoimmune diseases, including autoimmunity against the thymus, insula, and salivary glands. This is accompanied by a shift in the balance between Th17 and Treg cells. These findings indicate that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmune diseases and that its function is not limited to the early phase of T cell activation.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification and traced the evolution of genes enabling specialized plant feeding. Phylogenomic analyses of these uniquely comprehensive datasets resolved controversial beetle relationships and dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous. We propose that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that enable digestion of plant cell walls.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Our results show that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the design of experiments that investigate the role of culture in evolution. They also have implications for the design of societies, in which larger population sizes may not be the best way to enhance the cumulative cultural evolution of a society.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE E4 allele is associated with an ∼twofold increased risk for AD, whereas APOE E2 allele is associated with an ∼12-fold decreased risk for AD. APOE is a major component of the lipid core of the blood-brain barrier and is highly expressed in astrocytes, a major cell type of the central nervous system. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also found that APOE alleles affect the accumulation of a protein that is a component of the classical complement pathway in senescent synapses. The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is about 1,500 km in radius and 15 km in depth. It is the densest part of the Earth and is the only part of the Earth that is not in dynamic equilibrium with the rest of the Earth. The inner core is a unique natural laboratory for studying the physics and chemistry of the deep interior. The inner core is also a challenge for understanding the origin of the Earth. The inner core is thought to have formed by the crystallization of a liquid core. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. This paper provides a solution to the long-standing paradox of the inner core nucleation.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the drug is illegal, it is widely available, and its use is increasing. The effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are unknown. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA). Specifically, marijuana abusers had reduced decreases in striatal dopamine D2 receptor availability when challenged with methylphenidate. The reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability. These findings suggest that the reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate in marijuana abusers contributes to their addictive behaviors.

Language is a uniquely human cognitive skill, and the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending it are a major focus of neuroscience. However, the brain’s language system is highly complex, and it is difficult to understand how its many parts contribute to language comprehension. Here, we present a systematic study in which we link together many datasets and many computational models of language processing. We find that the most powerful models of language processing are also the most accurate at predicting neural and behavioral responses to sentences. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the brain’s mechanisms for comprehending language. They also suggest that predictive processing may be a promising target for developing more accurate language models in the future. (Show more)

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in recent years, but it is still an active area of research. One of the main challenges is that the training of deep neural networks is unstable, even when universal approximation properties guarantee the existence of stable neural networks. We address this paradox by demonstrating that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks, but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a neural network. This result implies a classification theory describing conditions under which (stable) neural networks can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. This paper discusses a classic experiment published 45 years ago that has been cited more than 1,000 times in the past 10 y. It shows that the experiment’s critical design flaws went unnoticed at the time and were only identified in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. The paper discusses the implications of this case study for the scientific community and society at large.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries. It is caused by two closely related bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which cause different forms of the disease. The two bacteria are very similar, but the cause of this similarity is not known. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that M. lepromatosis has retained the ability to infect the nervous system, whereas M. leprae has lost this ability. This suggests that M. lepromatosis may be a cause of leprosy neuropathy. The two bacteria are remarkably similar, and we estimate that they diverged from their MRCA approximately 14 Mya. This is the first time that the divergence of these two leprosy bacteria has been estimated. (Show more)

Entanglement and entropy are key concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also fundamental to thermodynamics, which is the study of the macroscopic properties of isolated systems. The interplay between these concepts is a central issue in quantum information theory and statistical physics. In this work, we study the entanglement dynamics in a paradigmatic model of quantum mechanics, the spin-1/2 Heisenberg chain, and show that it is possible to compute the entanglement entropy in the space–time scaling limit. This result is a milestone in the study of the entanglement dynamics and opens the way to a deeper understanding of the thermodynamics of isolated quantum systems.

Plague, caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis, is one of the most devastating diseases in human history. Today, most human plague cases are bubonic, caused by spillover of infected fleas from rodent epizootics, or pneumonic, caused by inhalation of infectious droplets. However, little is known about the historical spread of plague in Europe during the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries), including the Black Death, which led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. Here, we describe a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides a better understanding of the history of plague in Europe and may help to prevent future outbreaks. This article is protected by copyright. Copyright © 2020 The Author(s)

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density is still poorly understood. We present a comprehensive dataset of neuron numbers in amniotes and use it to reconstruct the evolution of brain neuronal density. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. Amniote brain evolution is characterized by the following four major shifts in neuron–brain scaling. The most dramatic increases in brain neurons occurred independently with the appearance of birds and mammals, resulting in convergent neuron scaling in the two endothermic lineages.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements in cells. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled. The actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family is the main regulator of actin filament disassembly. It is a key player in many cellular processes, including cell motility. However, how it does so is still not fully understood. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques, coupled to microfluidics, to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that the mechanical situation can have a dramatic effect on ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever actin filaments. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. This work provides a new perspective on the action of ADF/cofilin and opens new avenues for understanding and modulating actin filament disassembly in cells. It also provides a platform for developing new tools for single-molecule studies.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. This study compared the effects of fructose versus glucose on brain, hormone, and appetitive responses to food cues and food-approach behavior. We found that fructose versus glucose led to greater hunger and desire for food and a greater willingness to give up long-term monetary rewards to obtain immediate high-calorie foods. These findings suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior. Our results also suggest that the effects of fructose on brain and behavior may be mediated, at least in part, by the hormone insulin. Future studies are needed to determine the extent to which the effects of fructose on brain and behavior are specific to fructose or are a consequence of the effects of high-fructose corn syrup, which is a mixture of fructose and glucose. Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across Madagascar. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the settlement history of Madagascar. It also provides a reference for the genomic diversity of the Malagasy population. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a large-scale experiment, in which we randomly assigned people to see either positive or negative content in their News Feed. We found that people who saw more positive content produced less positive content and more negative content, and vice versa. This suggests that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This work also suggests that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

The vast majority of RNA in the cell is not protein-coding, and noncoding RNAs have a wide range of functions. One class of noncoding RNAs, called microRNAs, are known to regulate protein synthesis by targeting mRNAs for degradation or blocking translation. However, the majority of noncoding RNAs are not miRNAs, and the mechanisms by which they regulate protein synthesis are not well understood. We show that the presence of a single modification, called pseudouridine (Ψ), in messenger RNA can modestly alter translation speed and the rate of protein synthesis. Our findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in messenger RNA can have a subtle effect on protein synthesis. This study provides insight into the role of Ψ in mRNA sequences and may have implications for the function of other noncoding RNAs. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and more time spent in social activities and exercising. Longitudinally, worthwhile ratings predict positive changes in social, economic, health, and behavioral outcomes independently of baseline levels. These findings suggest that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. They also highlight the importance of the subjective experience of worthwhile activities in the maintenance of health and well-being across the life span. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining feature of the evolution of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms. Under this energetic model, thermoregulatory costs constrain minimum size, whereas limitations on feeding efficiency constrain maximum size. Rather than being released from size pressures, water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is one of the most common and most disruptive diseases in the world. The cold temperature of the nasal cavity is a major factor in the initiation of the cold virus infection. However, the mechanism by which the cold temperature favors virus replication is not well understood. Here, we show that mouse airway cells replicate rhinovirus more efficiently at the nasal cavity temperature than at core body temperature. We also show that the cold temperature favors the less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells. These findings provide insights into the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth of rhinovirus. They also suggest that the cold temperature may be a useful target for the development of antiviral drugs for the treatment of the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must sense and respond to changes in the external conditions. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses its type IV pili to sense and respond to the mechanical activity of these pilus structures. This mechanosensory system is essential for the pathogen to attach to surfaces and to regulate its virulence. Our findings demonstrate that type IV pili are not only used for twitching motility, but also as a sensor that regulates surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This study provides insights into the evolution of mechanosensory systems in bacteria. It also opens new perspectives for the development of new antibacterial strategies. (Show more)

The widespread use of pesticides in agriculture has led to a substantial contamination of surface waters. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and reveals that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results show that the majority of surface waters are at risk due to the presence of pesticides. This is a major concern, as pesticides are known to have negative effects on aquatic organisms. Our findings highlight the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the world, and the virus continues to spread. We report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection. We also show that the virus spread between deer and humans, highlighting the need for a “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. We anticipate that our findings will lead to a better understanding of the ecology of the virus and will help to inform future strategies to mitigate the spread of SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, biodiversity, and people. This paper examines the causes of this problem and proposes solutions. We show that the proliferation of large dams is a result of the industry moving to developing countries, the lack of consideration of climate change, and the lack of consideration of the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. We propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) hypothesis has been the focus of intense research for the past 30 y. However, the underlying mechanisms of Aβ-mediated neuroinflammation remain unclear. Here, we show that soluble Aβ species are toxic to neurons and induce a proinflammatory response. We also demonstrate that neighboring glial cells do not express the same molecules, suggesting that neurons are the primary source of inflammation in AD. Finally, we show that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a vulnerable region in the human brain, suggesting that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ may be a significant contributor to AD pathogenesis. These findings provide insight into the neuroinflammation that occurs in AD and may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is today one of the most widespread domesticated species and is a main source of protein in the human diet. However, for thousands of years exploitation of chickens was confined to symbolic and social domains such as cockfighting. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method to study the folding of a large protein in high structural detail. We have applied this method to maltose binding protein, a protein that folds in a complex manner. We have found that the folding of the protein is a multistep process.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a critical mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. We also show that RppH prefers to decapsulate Np4-capped RNAs over their capped counterparts, and that the enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature, such as earthquakes, avalanches, or forest fires, where a system undergoes a phase transition from a noncritical to a critical state. In the critical state, the system is characterized by a power-law distribution of the sizes of the events. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of the times between events. In this paper, we study a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We show that the distribution of the times between events is a stretched exponential, and we discuss the implications of our results for the understanding of the underlying mechanism of SOC.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. The temperature history of Earth is a key factor in understanding the origin and evolution of life. The isotopic record of the oceans, however, has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes derived from light-requiring prokaryotic and eukaryotic phototrophs having widely separated fossil-based divergence ages. The ancestral environmental temperatures thereby determined for these photic-zone organisms––shown in modern taxa to correlate strongly with thermostability––are inferred to reflect ancient surface-environment paleotemperatures. Our results suggest that Earth's surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the main ion-conductive elements in cells and are important for many physiological and pathological processes. Ion channels are also the main targets of drugs. Ion channels are open or closed, and the open probability is determined by the channel’s conformation. Ion channels have two types of conformational gates, one for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other for slow channel inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Malaria is a devastating disease that affects millions of people worldwide. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection is well established, the impact of humidity on disease outcome is less clear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity increases susceptibility to severe disease following influenza virus infection. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in mice deficient in the antiviral enzyme caspase-1/11. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the impact of ambient humidity on host defense and disease outcome during influenza infection. The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and sentences at the top. However, this description is based on a model of language that is not supported by neurophysiological evidence. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the construction of a sentence is not sequential, but rather unfolds in a tree-like fashion, with each word contributing to the construction of a phrase. Our results suggest that the brain uses a bottom-up parser to build a hierarchy of nested phrases from the incoming language stream. This parser may be a key to understanding the brain’s processing of language.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that regulates a wide range of processes, including cell proliferation, differentiation, and migration. Axin is a key component of the pathway, and its activity is tightly regulated. We show here that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are not only similar at the protein level but also genetically redundant. We demonstrate that differential regulation of the two forms of Axin on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This work provides a deeper understanding of the regulation of the canonical Wnt pathway. It also provides a model for the regulation of other redundant gene pairs in vertebrates. This work may also provide a basis for the development of new therapeutic strategies for diseases caused by defects in the canonical Wnt pathway.

Obesity is a major health concern, and the mechanisms that regulate food intake are not fully understood. Here we show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus (LH) induces vigorous eating in sated mice. We found that this effect is mediated by LH neurons that project to the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc), where they inhibit dopamine neurons. We also found that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of LH neurons or the VTA. Finally, we show that LH stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of peri-LH GABA neurons, which project to the locus coeruleus (LC), where they inhibit dopamine neurons. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This work provides a framework for future studies of the neural circuits that regulate food intake. (PsycINFO Database Record

The Amazon is losing forest at an alarming rate. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are used to inform forest monitoring and conservation efforts, but the alerts are often too late to deter deforestation. We study a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to detect and localize sounds in their environment. The auditory organs of animals are diverse in anatomy and are part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius uses its web as an external auditory organ to sense and localize acoustic waves. The web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense acoustic waves and is able to detect and localize the source of an incoming acoustic wave. The spider can also adjust and regenerate its web to suit its needs. This provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides insights into the evolution of extended and regenerative sensing and design. The climate and health impacts of anthropogenic aerosols and greenhouse gases are difficult to disentangle. We used a global model to estimate the climate and health outcomes of a phaseout of fossil fuels, indicating the potential benefits of a rapid phaseout. We show that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Globally, fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. Aerosols affect the hydrologic cycle, contributing to water and food security. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. The climate and health benefits are likely to be even larger if the model is improved by including the effects of aerosols on the hydrologic cycle. This study is timely because of the recent Paris climate agreement.

The neuroblastoma-associated kinase ALK is a protooncogene that is activated by mutations in the majority of neuroblastomas. The plague bacterium Yersinia pestis has caused devastating outbreaks throughout human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a well-established fact. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This information is critical for understanding the origins of plague and its impact on human history. (Show more)

Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management of agricultural lands is often at odds with SOC sequestration, as intensive crop production on grassland-derived Mollisols liberates massive amounts of carbon to the atmosphere. We show that soil management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can sequester SOC on these soils. These practices also improve soil health, as demonstrated by enhanced soil microbial biomass, activity, and nutrient cycling. Our results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester carbon on agricultural lands and highlight the need for more research on the effects of soil management on SOC sequestration in grasslands worldwide.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify risk factors for zoonotic spillover and developed a framework to estimate the risk of a virus spillover to humans. We then applied this framework to 887 wildlife viruses, ranking them according to their potential to cause future spillover and spread in humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. We anticipate that the SpillOver platform will be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. (Less)

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to animals for pollination. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators. In this study, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work cumulatively identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a molecular basis for the study of vertebrate-pollinated plants.

We present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 450 and 750 AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity. This heterogeneity includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. Particularly striking are women with artificial skull deformations; the analysis of their collective genetic ancestry suggests an origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, functional variants revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how HKU4 and HKU5 transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origin of MERS-CoV and the potential risk of HKU4 and HKU5 for human infections. They also provide a basis for the development of effective

The global spread of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens has led to a global need for rapid pathogen identification. We used a cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to identify a diverse range of pathogens in a periurban hospital in Cambodia. We identified dengue virus as the most common pathogen, but also detected underappreciated zoonotic pathogens, such as Plasmodium knowlesi, leptospirosis, and coinfecting HIV. We also identified chikungunya virus as an early indicator of a national outbreak. Our findings highlight the potential of mNGS to identify a broad range of pathogens in resource-scarce settings. Coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template during DNA replication. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results suggest that the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is not as tightly regulated as previously thought and that the human pol δ holoenzyme may be more similar to the S. cerevisiae pol δ holoenzyme than previously thought. This study provides a unique insight into the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for DNA replication. The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In an effort toward reconstructing RNA-based life in the laboratory, in vitro evolution was used to improve dramatically the activity and generality of an RNA polymerase ribozyme by selecting variants that can synthesize functional RNA molecules from an RNA template. The improved polymerase ribozyme is able to synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease, and the mortality rate is high. The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the stage of exploration. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, may be a potential treatment for COVID-19. We retrospectively analyzed the clinical efficacy of tocilizumab in severe and critical COVID-19 patients. The results showed that tocilizumab could improve the clinical symptoms and reduce mortality. Therefore, tocilizumab may be a potential treatment for COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but its excess is toxic. The ability to control copper levels is therefore an important aspect of fungal physiology. In this study, we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a copper-binding isocyanide metabolite. The presence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a role for this pathway in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This study also demonstrates that the xan BGC is functional in Aspergillus fumigatus, and that the xan BGC isocyanide products have significant antimicrobial properties. These findings suggest that the xan BGC is a promising target for the development of antifungal agents. This study also demonstrates that the xan BGC is a promising target for the development of antifungal agents. The formation of silica-rich minerals in a sedimentary environment is rare on Earth and on Mars. The detection of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is a significant discovery. Tridymite is a high-temperature (>870 °C) silica polymorph that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary environment on Mars is a unique discovery. The diagenesis of tridymite and other silica-rich minerals in a sedimentary environment is a new process on Mars. The diagenesis of silica-rich minerals in a sedimentary environment is a new process on Earth.

Frost damage is a major threat to plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is not random but rather is shaped by the evolutionary history of the species. We also show that the resistance strategies of species are not fixed but rather are flexible and can change in response to environmental changes. Our findings can help decision-makers to anticipate the impact of frost damage on ecosystems and to adapt to it.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the developmental origins of these cells are unknown. Using a Th17 transfer model of colitis, we found that Th17 cells could not induce disease in recipients lacking IFN-γ. In contrast, development of disease required the transition of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells and was contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, Th17 cells could provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. This plasticity may be important for the development of disease in inflammatory bowel disease. Understanding the developmental origins of Th17 cells may lead to the development of novel therapeutic strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes and different clinical courses. The disease is also progressive, with motor neuron degeneration occurring in the spinal cord, brainstem, and cortex. The disease is fatal, with a median survival of 2.5 y. There is no cure, and there is no way to predict who will die and when. The ability of pathogens to influence the composition of the insect microbiota is poorly understood. Here, we show that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), a protein that alters the composition of the tick microbiota. We demonstrate that iafgp alters the integrity of the peritrophic matrix and gut barrier, which are critical obstacles for Anaplasma colonization. Mechanistically, iafgp binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the pentapeptide chain of bacterial peptidoglycan, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the microbiota of their vectors and may have implications for the control of vector-borne diseases. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of vertebrates. However, the origin of the modern avian body plan is still a matter of debate. Here, we describe a basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. This discovery increases the known diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding the evolution of the avian body plan.

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a wide variety of colors, from red to blue. The color of an animal can be used to communicate its identity, warn of danger, or blend in with its surroundings. In this study, we show that the color of some animals can be changed by the presence of a specific protein. This protein binds biliverdin, a pigment that is normally found in the blood. We describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death in women. Breast cancer cells are heterogeneous, with distinct properties that contribute to their malignant behavior. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are a subpopulation of cells that are responsible for tumor initiation and metastasis. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the expression of the pluripotency factor NANOG and the BCSC phenotype. These findings suggest that ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. This study also provides insight into the role of ALKBH5 in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. The parchment used to make the first pocket Bibles was so thin that it was almost transparent. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds in China. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. This study establishes an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays a critical role in the regulation of various biological processes, including metabolism, cancer, and circadian rhythm. Here, we generate intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. Together, we demonstrate that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune response of the host. We have determined the structure of the spike protein in complex with the receptor-binding domain of ACE2. We show that the D614G mutation in the spike protein has little effect on the structure of the protein, but does change the conformation of the spike protein. This change may facilitate the binding of the virus to the receptor.

We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. Black and Latino Americans have experienced a disproportionate burden of COVID-19 morbidity and mortality, reflecting persistent structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites.
