The chemical properties of atoms are essential to understand the chemistry of compounds. In this work, we study the evolution of chemical properties of atoms under pressure. We find that chemical hardness and electronegativity decrease with pressure, consistent with pressure-induced metallization. Furthermore, we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work provides a new perspective on the chemistry of atoms under pressure. It also provides a new perspective on the chemistry of atoms under pressure.

Fire is a key ecosystem process, but its role in climate change is poorly understood. We show that changes in fire activity, driven by climate, socioeconomic, and demographic factors, can have a significant impact on the global carbon cycle. We find that changes in fire activity have acted to warm climate throughout most of the 20th century. However, recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may reverse this, enhancing land carbon uptake and corresponding to offsetting ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. This potentially reduces warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. Our study highlights that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate, and that the risk of more extreme fires regionally is a concern. Our results have implications for understanding the role of fire in climate change and for managing fire regimes in a changing world.

The symbiotic relationship between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont Vibrio fischeri is a classic example of a mutualism. The squid provides a protected environment for the bacteria, which in turn provide a source of light for the host. We show here that the squid regulates the provision of a critical nutrient to its symbionts, chitin, and that this regulation is necessary for the persistence of the symbiosis. We propose that other animal hosts may similarly regulate the activities of symbionts associated with epithelial tissues.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We draw on advances in theoretical machine learning to integrate topic modeling and word embedding, capitalizing on their distinct capabilities. Our method is motivated by the need to understand the gendered nature of violent death narratives. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. We believe this will be of interest to researchers in a wide range of fields.

The Black Death, originating in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague and its impact on human societies. It also provides a new approach to study the history of infectious diseases. (Show more)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and play a key role in the ecosystem. However, they are also a major prey item for a variety of predators. In the Northeast Pacific, the sea star (asteroid) wasting disease (SSWD) has caused extensive mortality of asteroids. We show that the disease is caused by a densovirus. We also show that the disease is highly contagious and that the virus can be transmitted between asteroids and to nonasteroid echinoderms. This suggests that the disease is spread by the water and that the virus is a major threat to the ecosystem.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study also provides a proof-of-concept for the use of antibody-mediated therapy in AML. This approach may be applicable to other hematological malignancies. Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human population. The island is located ∼400 km from the east coast of Africa, but its genetic and linguistic traits are from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GlpD) and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR). Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. (Show more)

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, the information they provide is often qualitative and subjective, and is not easily integrated into quantitative models. We show that the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which collects crop status information from a large number of crop experts, can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that is statistically robust and maintains similar characteristics across different crops. We discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data. Finally, we propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on the CPC survey and demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed methodology can be extended to other countries and crops.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain. Our model is based on the idea that memory is supported by a form of synaptic plasticity that reduces the firing rate of neurons. This adaptive change in excitability is dependent on experience and can be used to store information. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. Our model provides a neurobiological substrate for memory that is sensitive to context and serial order. It is also sensitive to the time constant of adaptation, which determines memory span. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a powerful tool for understanding the evolution of photosynthesis and the origin of eukaryotic cells. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the vulnerability of cities to climate change. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work provides a valuable contribution to the ongoing debate on the role of anthropogenic climate change in the 2015–2017 Cape Town drought. (Abridged)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which they form are not well understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this anthropogenic quasicrystal, with its unique history, provides a unique opportunity to study the conditions under which quasicrystals form and to test our understanding of the structure of quasicrystals.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. (Bacterio)chlorophylls have an isocyclic fifth ring, the formation of which has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the O2-dependent enzyme. Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). Neuroinflammation is a complex process that involves multiple cell types, including microglia, astrocytes, and neurons. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of EAE in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a better understanding of the roles of ASK1 in neuroinflammation. California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and now includes the lowest calendar-year and 12-mo precipitation, the highest annual temperature, and the most extreme drought indicators on record. The extremely warm and dry conditions have led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits in California were more than twice as likely to yield drought years if they occurred when conditions were warm. We find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. In addition, the probability that precipitation deficits co-occur with warm conditions and the probability that precipitation deficits produce drought have both increased. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder that affects social interaction and communication. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. As an alternative approach, extensive efforts have been devoted to identifying the convergence of the targets and functions of the autism-risk genes to facilitate mapping out causal paths. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results show that this is indeed the case, but they also highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The store-operated Ca2+ (Ca2+)$$ channel (SOCC) is a highly regulated Ca2+ channel that plays a critical role in a variety of cellular functions. Loss-of-function mutations in the pore-forming protein of the SOCC, ORAI1, or in the Ca2+ sensor of the SOCC, STIM1, result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 associated with a Stormorken syndrome of hematological abnormalities, bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular aggregate myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated SOCC signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the SOCC, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of the disease process. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are not well understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spread of aggregates in the Drosophila brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We demonstrate that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, indicating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and suggest that targeting the release of aggregates may be a promising therapeutic strategy. Here, we identified and characterized a protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX inhibits the antiviral immune response of the host and facilitates viral infection by selectively inhibiting the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX has no effect on the aminopeptidase function of LTA4H and therefore does not impair the antiinflammatory function of LTA4H. MTX potently inhibits proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. SHMT is up-regulated in cancer, and the mitochondrial isozyme is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 blocks colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2. We show that formate generally rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. We show that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import in DLBCL cell lines, rendering them uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a foundation for the development of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2, and for the development of SHMT-targeted therapies for cancer. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous neurodegenerative disease with a high mortality rate. The disease is caused by mutations in a number of genes, including SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS. We observe that the inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The results are expected to be of interest to researchers in many areas, including atom optics, quantum optics, and many-body physics. The origin of the flowering plants is a major evolutionary event that has been poorly understood. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the origin of the aquatic flowering plants is even less understood. The research presented here centers on Montsechia vidalii, a fossil plant from the early Cretaceous Pyrenees of Spain. This fossil plant has been poorly understood and misinterpreted in the past. Now, based upon the study of more than 1,000 carefully prepared specimens, a detailed analysis of Montsechia is presented. The morphology and anatomy of the plant, including aspects of its reproduction, suggest that Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum (whenever cladistic analyses are made with or without a backbone). Montsechia was an aquatic angiosperm living and reproducing below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is Barremian in age, raising questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade compared with its position as sister to eudicots in many cladistic analyses. The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (∼0.5–6.9 kya) from Eurasia and Greenland. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising around the world, and this rise is accelerating. The acceleration is a result of a combination of factors, including climate change, land subsidence, and tectonic plate motion. We estimate that the climate change component of the acceleration is 0.055 ± 0.025 mm/y2, and that the climate change component of the global mean sea level rise is 2.4 ± 0.4 mm/y. This is in agreement with the IPCC 5th Assessment Report (AR5) model projections.

Pain is a normal part of life, but it is not normal to have pain. In this paper, we show that pain has increased for all adults in America, but it has increased more for those born after 1950 than for those born before 1950. This is a mystery, because it is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. Instead, it is explained by the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment available for MERS. Here, we show that remdesivir, an investigational broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the further development of remdesivir as a potential treatment for MERS. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of continued basic and translational research to identify effective antiviral treatments for emerging and reemerging infectious diseases. The data presented here are also relevant to the emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. The symbiotic relationship between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont Vibrio fischeri is a classic example of a mutualism. The squid provides a protected environment for the bacteria, which in turn provide a source of light for the host. We show here that the squid regulates the provision of a critical nutrient to its symbionts, chitin, which is delivered in a precise quantity and at a precise time. We also show that the timing of chitin delivery is essential for the symbiosis to persist. This work suggests that the squid may be able to control the activities of its symbionts through the strategic provision of nutrients, whose catabolism modulates conditions like pH or anoxia in the symbionts’ habitat. This work may have implications for other symbioses in which the host regulates the activities of its symbionts. (Show more)

This paper reports on a series of experiments and field trials that test the impact of a brief, online intervention to encourage teachers to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. The intervention was evaluated in three districts, in three states, and in three countries. It was found to reduce year-long suspension rates by half. Moreover, it bolstered the respect that at-risk students had for teachers and bolstered the motivation of these students to behave well in class. This paper contributes to the literature on the impact of punitive discipline on students and teachers and to the literature on the impact of teacher mindsets on student outcomes. It also contributes to the literature on the impact of online interventions on student outcomes.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages of MERS-CoV spike (S) glycoproteins. These mutations compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses trafficked past cell-surface proteases and into endosomes, whereas precleaved viruses used endosomal fusion-activating proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry. Uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Here we apply quantitative proteomics to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in an isogenic breast epithelial cell line stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not present in SARS-CoV. This structure provides insight into the molecular basis for the rapid spread of the disease and the immune suppression observed in patients. Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening condition, but the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we report that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this effect is mediated by the hypoxic induction of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1), aquaporin-4 (AQP4), and endothelin-1 (ET-1) in the cortex. We also show that, in cultured astrocytes, hypoxia triggers cortical release of CRF, which acts on CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of AQP4 and cerebral edema. The scientific enterprise is based on the idea that we can learn from data. This is a powerful idea, but it is not without its challenges. In this paper, we describe a challenge that arises when we have a large dataset and we want to find associations in it. This challenge is particularly important in the era of big data. We describe some recent developments in selective inference that can help us to address this challenge.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular ECs (ETVECs). ETV2-mediated conversion of fibroblasts into ETVECs is accompanied by the up-regulation of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1. ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in mice. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This study also provides a promising therapeutic approach for ischemic disorders and the regeneration of organs. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of influenza A viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and nonspecifically decreases the amount of viral RNA in the viral particles, resulting in an eightfold increase in empty viral particles. Our experiments indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, in the 20th century, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-caused fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Zika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne flavivirus that has recently emerged as a cause of severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The dynamics of ZIKV within the host are not well understood. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV dynamics in a nonhuman primate model. We estimate the within-host basic reproductive number, the rate of viral production, and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus. We also assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Our results can help guide the design of effective antiviral treatment strategies. (Show more)

Coral reefs are the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on the planet. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors, including climate change. One of the most severe impacts of climate change on coral reefs is the breakdown of the symbiotic relationship between the reef-building coral and its algal partner. This process is known as coral bleaching. While the symptoms of bleaching are well known, the underlying causes remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic activity of the coral host is the primary driver of the breakdown of the symbiosis. Our findings provide insights into the physiological and molecular processes that lead to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis and may help us to understand the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its metabolic interactions. This may ultimately help us to predict the fate of coral reefs in a changing world.

The intestinal epithelium is a barrier to the environment and a hub for communication with the microbiota. In this study, we show that intestinal tumors can alter the composition of the microbiome and trigger a regenerative response in the epithelium. We identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. We also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work provides insights into the crosstalk between tumors and the microbiome and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death in women. Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients relapse. Here we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. Finally, treatment of PDX-bearing mice with cirmtuzumab and paclitaxel was more effective than treatment with either alone in eradicating breast cancer PDXs. Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, freshwater fisheries are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. Here, we provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. Our analysis also reveals that fishing pressure is most intense in rivers where potential impacts on biodiversity are highest. This syndrome of poverty, nutritional deficiency, fishery dependence, and extrinsic threats to biodiverse river ecosystems underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system. In mammals, this ability is lost during development, and the adult CNS is incapable of regenerating. In contrast, regeneration is a well-known phenomenon in the developing nervous system. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration in the adult nervous system that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of the nervous system and is dependent on sensory activity and calcium signaling. Our study provides a unique platform for the discovery of genes involved in the control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity.

Recombination is a fundamental process in the generation of genetic diversity. In sexually reproducing organisms, it is essential for the formation of genetic linkages between homologous chromosomes during meiosis. In the past decade, the advent of next-generation sequencing technologies has made it possible to map recombination events in a genome with unprecedented accuracy. Here, we use this technology to map recombination events in a wild population of the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions showing no detectable recombination. This variation is similar to that observed in yeast and in mice, suggesting that recombination patterns in flowering plants may be conserved across evolution.

The resting brain is a complex system, with a large number of functionally interconnected networks. The identification of these networks is a key step in understanding the brain’s organization and function. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant metabolic RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during task performance, and this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This study illustrates the potential of metabolic imaging to provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of eukaryotic messenger RNA (mRNA). It is essential for efficient translation and is also involved in mRNA export and stability. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group. We show that NAD+ is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We also show that NAD+ is produced cotranscriptionally, suggesting that it may play a role in regulating the stability and translation of specific subsets of mRNAs. This discovery of a second 5′ modification in eukaryotes raises the possibility that it may also have a role in regulating mRNA function.

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) showed that intensive glucose control can prevent the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. However, the long-term effects of intensive glucose control on the progression of complications are not fully understood. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci in blood cells of people with diabetes are associated with the effects of intensive glucose control during the DCCT on the progression of complications in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study also shows that epigenetic DNA-me alterations in blood cells of people with diabetes are persistent for several years after the end of the DCCT. This finding supports the hypothesis that epigenetic DNA-me alterations are a potential mechanism for the long-term effects of intensive glucose control on the progression of complications in the EDIC Study. This study also provides a foundation for future studies to examine the effects of epigenetic DNA-me alterations on the progression of complications in people with diabetes. These studies should also examine the effects of epigenetic DNA-me alterations on the progression of complications in people without diabetes.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The etiology of this disorder is multifactorial, but the role of the gut microbiota in its development has recently been highlighted. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence. These results suggest that the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota may be a promising therapeutic target for the treatment of this disease.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals that contribute to the overall aroma. Among these volatiles are several aromatic and aliphatic nitrogen-containing compounds for which the biosynthetic pathways are not known. Using an introgression population derived from Solanum pennellii, we identified a locus essential for the production of all the detectable nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. Silencing of the underlying gene in transgenic plants abolished production of aliphatic and aromatic nitrogenous volatiles in ripe fruit, and metabolomic analysis of these fruit revealed the accumulation of 2-isobutyl-tetrahydrothiazolidine-4-carboxylic acid, a known conjugate of cysteine and 3-methylbutanal. Biosynthetic incorporation of stable isotope-labeled precursors into 2-isobutylthiazole and 2-phenylacetonitrile confirmed that cysteine provides the nitrogen atom for all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This pathway is a major step forward in understanding and ultimately improving tomato flavor quality. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these threats are frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the conservation of biodiversity and the maintenance of ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-running behavior. We found that grid cells, which are essential for spatial navigation, are anatomically segregated from other cell types. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of MEC and suggest that grid cells are not simply a subset of other cell types. This study provides a framework for future studies of the functional organization of MEC. (PsycINFO Database Record

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of environmental and developmental signals. In this study, we show that the FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) gene is not required for flowering of the host plant in a parasitic plant–host plant interaction. Instead, FTs are able to move from the host to the parasitic plant, where they interact with a dodder FD transcription factor to induce flowering. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-producing cells of the substantia nigra. The disease is associated with a loss of dopamine-containing neurons and a reduction in the activity of dopamine-producing neurons. The present study shows that dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra are connected to other brain regions by a system of specialized neuronal formations. These formations, termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” are composed of striosomes, dopamine-containing neurons, and other cells of the nigrostriatal system. The striosome–dendron bouquets are likely to be critical to the function of the dopamine system in health and disease.

We all feel connected to others, but how do we know when we’re feeling connected to someone? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed with which we respond to others is a robust and sufficient signal of connection. We found that people felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. This signal was used by third-party listeners to predict how connected two people felt to each other. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for heart rate control and are characterized by a unique Ca2+ release mechanism. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is selectively expressed in SANCs and plays a critical role in Ca2+ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) of SANCs. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of SR Ca2+ stores of SANCs and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. Moreover, STIM1 influenced SAN function by regulating ionic fluxes in SANCs, including activation of a store-operated Ca2+ current, a reduction in L-type Ca2+ current, and enhancing the activities of Na+/Ca2+ exchanger. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. Although the function of Si in plant physiology has been well documented, its beneficial effects on plant resistance against insect herbivory have been less well studied. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by jasmonic acid (JA), a key signaling molecule in plant defense responses. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact in rice defense against insect herbivory. This study provides insights into the potential role of Si in insect resistance and may lead to the development of Si-based pest management strategies. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, an enzyme involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results suggest that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of macrophage lipid metabolism.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that involves the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain. Our model is based on the idea that memory is supported by a form of synaptic plasticity that reduces the firing rate of neurons. This adaptive change in excitability is dependent on experience and can be used to store information. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. Our model provides a neurobiological substrate for memory that is sensitive to context and serial order. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenging task, and the delivery of functional biomolecules such as RNA is even more difficult. Here, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery of the cargo across the cell wall. We also show that the delivery of the cargo depends on the endogenous gene silencing pathway. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a step toward the development of a plant-based delivery system for functional biomolecules. (Show more)

Eutrophication is a major threat to the world’s lakes and coastal ecosystems. In the United States, the majority of nutrient inputs to lakes come from small tributaries, which drain large surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large watersheds, leaving small tributaries largely unaddressed. We show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to lakes, especially in nearshore areas. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small tributaries to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the rare combination of initial conditions is required to produce the observed fine-tuned structure of the universe. Our results suggest that the same mechanism may be at work in the design of chemical networks.

The mechanisms by which NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) cause autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs change the intrinsic cortical microcircuit and neuronal population dynamics to alter the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity and predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. Based on local field potential recordings in a mouse model, we validate a dynamic causal model of NMDAR-Ab effects on cortical microcircuitry. Using this model, we identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes render microcircuitry critically susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms when these key parameters are changed, even though the same parameter fluctuations are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. This work may help to guide the development of new therapies for this devastating disease. The history of abrupt climate change is a key area of research in Earth system science. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was associated with a global warming and a doubling of atmospheric CO2. We also show that this event was associated with an injection of organic matter–derived carbon into the ocean. This carbon was associated with anoxia and nutrient release, which may have led to a biodiversity nadir. Our results highlight the importance of studying abrupt climate change events in the context of the Earth system. This is important for understanding the potential impacts of climate change on the biosphere and for understanding the potential for feedbacks between climate and biosphere. (Show more)

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical forest loss, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production was certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in 2017. However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we use a comprehensive dataset of RSPO-certified and noncertified oil palm plantations (∼188,000 km2) in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil, as well as annual remotely sensed metrics of tree cover loss and fire occurrence, to evaluate the impact of certification on deforestation and fire. Our results suggest that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia. Nevertheless, most plantations contained little residual forest when they received certification. As a result, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. The exocyst complex is essential for the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the functioning of all kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In this study, we discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an individual is often a defining characteristic of its phenotype. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, which can be either male- or female-determining. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, the sex of an individual can be determined by multiple loci, resulting in a spectrum of sex classes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that multiple alleles can produce a modular interplay of sex linkage and sex limitation, resulting in a spectrum of sexual phenotypes. This provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of bisretinoids that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyls bearing species. In mice treated with the Fe chelator deferiprone (DFP), intracellular Fe levels, as reflected in transferrin receptor mRNA expression, were reduced. DFP-treated albino Abca4−/− and agouti wild-type mice exhibited elevated bisretinoid levels as measured by high-performance liquid chromatography or noninvasively by quantitative fundus autofluorescence. Thinning of the outer nuclear layer, a parameter indicative of the loss of photoreceptor cell viability, was also reduced in DFP-treated albino Abca4−/−. Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the study of predator evolution is therefore fundamental to understand how ecosystems function. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as predators become increasingly dependent on a single prey type. Here we show that this is not the case, and that specialization can evolve into generalism, and that generalists can evolve into specialists on other prey types. Our findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also help to build a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological innovation and evolution. These findings are fundamental to understand how ecosystems function.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. The fossil record for the evolution of the human hand is incomplete, however, and the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the hand, the third metacarpal styloid process, is unknown. Here we report the discovery of this feature in a 1.42-Myr-old hominin fossil from Kenya. This fossil thus provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This fossil also provides a rare glimpse of the evolution of the hand in the early hominin lineage. Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus a metabolic target. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. Folate one-carbon units support purine and thymidine synthesis, and thus cell growth. Mammals have both cytosolic SHMT1 and mitochondrial SHMT2, with the mitochondrial isozyme strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual SHMT knockout blocks colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of human SHMT1/2, and show that one-carbon donor formate generally rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. This work provides a metabolic rationale for targeting SHMT in cancer. It also provides a metabolic rationale for targeting formate metabolism in cancer. Finally, it provides a metabolic rationale for targeting the glycine import pathway in cancer. Collectively, these findings provide a metabolic rationale for targeting the glycine import pathway in cancer. The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. In this study, we show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Modern agriculture is a major contributor to global food production, but it comes at a cost of soil degradation. Soil compaction is a major threat to soil productivity, but it is difficult to assess its spatial extent. We developed a global map of subsoil compaction risk based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the recent discovery of a 150-million-year-old footprint of a sauropod in the Morrison Formation of Colorado, USA. The discovery suggests that the mechanical footprint of sauropods may have been a major driver of the Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction.
